## Meet the Penguins
```{r include = FALSE}
penguins <- read.csv("../data/data.csv")
```


<div style="display: flex; align-items: center;">
  <p>The `penguins` data from the [palmerpenguins](https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/) package [@horstPalmerpenguinsV0102020]
 contains size measurements for `r nrow(penguins)` penguins from three species observed on three islands in the Palmer Archipelago, Antarctica.</p>
  <img src="https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/reference/figures/lter_penguins.png" alt="penguins" style="margin-left: 20px; width: 200px;">
</div>

### Number of Penguins per species
- There are `r sum(penguins$Species=='Chinstrap penguin (Pygoscelis antarctica)')` penguins of the Chinstrap species in the dataset.
- There are `r sum(penguins$Species=='Gentoo penguin (Pygoscelis papua)')` penguins of the Gentoo species in the dataset.
- There are `r sum(penguins$Species=='Adelie Penguin (Pygoscelis adeliae)')` penguins of the Adelie species in the dataset.


This means, the Chinstrap and Gentoo penguins together are `68+124` penguins.

## Results 
The plot below shows the relationship between flipper and bill lengths of these penguins.


```{r Plotting Penguins, echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
# Plot penguins
ggplot(penguins, 
       aes(x = `Flipper.Length..mm.`, y = `Culmen.Length..mm.`)) +
        geom_point(aes(color = Species, shape = Species)) +
        scale_color_manual(values = c("darkorange","purple","cyan4")) +
        labs(
                title = "Flipper and Culmen length",
                subtitle = "Dimensions for penguins at Palmer Station LTER",
                x = "Flipper length (mm)", y = "Culmen length (mm)",
                color = "Penguin species", shape = "Penguin species"
        ) +
        theme_minimal()
```
